intro: Ranunculus pedatus subsp. trojanus, commonly known as the Trojan buttercup, is a herbaceous perennial native to the Balkan Peninsula. It features showy, yellow flowers with five to seven petals, typically blooming in early spring. The plant has palmately lobed leaves and prefers moist, well-drained soils in partial shade. It is often found in woodland edges and meadows, and it is valued for its ornamental appeal in gardens. Its subspecific name, *trojanus*, alludes to its historical association with the Trojan region.
